First Taste of Learnings (2025-06-12)

Rust Fully Asynchronous BlueSky-like study

First Async Application in Rust (and first fully async backend ever!)

Recently I‚Äôve been trying to get my head around how to use async within the Rust context. I‚Äôve had some previous experience using async within Python helping to make non-blocking calls for embeddings of identified terms as they were independent. Although - I had some prior experience I was still greatly intimidated and had put off learning async within - many developers who appear much more talented had spoke of how difficult it was to understand the model.

Don‚Äôt Be Scared Jump In

Surprisingly transitioning my message board-like or blueskylike from leetcode into fully async wasn‚Äôt terribly difficult. First I worked through several problems in async which focused upon using a notifications and then streaming and without much practice I jumped in.

The api structure being mostly async really was just focused around learning the tools

  • Axum‚Äôs api-tree and server
  • Serde to communicate with json and handle the barier between client and server
  • Tokio for the async run-time and for the async sync handler RwLock
  • std::sync::Arc for having an atomic reference counter for the different people allowing to clone without actually needing to clone the data

But my favourtie package which was the stand out for me‚Ä¶

What the data looked like on the backend

Within the project one of the main api‚Äôs and handlin I needed to port was the fn follow(...) which takes in a followee_id and a follower_id. I wished to be able to have users write safetly to their own portion of the data ie the user (the follower) clicks follow on a person (the followee) and we remember this information.

This was a little bit difficult to model well the user should only be able to modify their own data, it should be able to be fully async‚Ä¶

The data appeared within the synchronous code as

Hashmap<UserId, HashSet<UserId>>

Which is simply a mapping from a user id to a set of users that they follow. A set was used in order to have quick unfollows O(1), as well as knowing all users shouldn‚Äôt duplicately follow other users.

First Iteration

In order to model the problem I had decided perhaps we use a Mutex. Mutex was a useful pattern in solving the leetcodes and allowed me to mutate data within asynchronous code to lets start there.

Mutex<HashSet, Mutex<UserId>>

This worked but it was blocking. This was fully synchronous code masquerading as the async. It was time to explore the other structures beyond what I had initially seen in my limited async Rust exposure.

Enter RwLock (Read-Write-Lock)

My api naturally could logically be modeled and partitioned into both read and write actions.

  • ReadAction: NewsFeed
  • WriteAction : Follow, Publish, Unfollow

This seemed like a natural way to model the problem so lets implement it.

The data then became modeled as

RwLock<Hashmap<UserId, RwLock<HashSet<UserId>>>

along with a couple of code changes : .lock().await -> .read().await or .write().await, but overall the changes were very minimal

RwLock was a major gain beyond a Mutex (Mutex is like a lock so only a single user or thread can have access to data). RwLock enabled multiple users to read from the data asynchronously and in parallel

‚Ä¶but the problem remained, and most of my actions actually cause side-effects and need to be writes but unfortunately the outer most Read-Write-Lock caused the entire ‚Äúbackend‚Äù to be blocked on a single write and even users reading would be locked during a single write.

Multiple user‚Äôs writing to the same location‚Ä¶ even though they should be seperate b/c a user should only write to their specific point‚Ä¶ This problem should be abled to be modeled. How can i drive this seperation?

Dashmap the Sleeper King

The problem seemed so simple‚Ä¶ just read-write lock on the interior data. Enter Dashmap, dashmap does exactly this, it was like Gandalf the Grey coming over the hill in Lord of the Rings!

Dashmap allows users to write to write to their private data without causing a need for explicit mutability and.. and is a near drop-in replacement for HashMap

ie

fn follow(&mut self, followee_id:UserId, follower_id:UserId)

became

fn follow(&self, followee_id:UserId, follower_id:UserId)

This helped to clear some of the trickier parts of Axum‚Äôs Server model and guarantees needed in order to build the api-tree interface. Dashmap enables this private mutation as long as you handle the interior part ie as long as the DashMap<UserId: **RwLock<HashSet<UserId>>**.

This was the exact model I was searching for - I cannot recommend the library enough if you are facing a similar modeling problem where something feels like it should be possible.

Takeaway

Not only is Rust async and the tooling around ever becoming ever more mature and viable tools in the workspace but‚Ä¶

Don‚Äôt be scared to jump in to the technology - you‚Äôve already solved many problems which felt difficult at the time and you succeeded them, this is just one more problem. When I saw the project handle a 1000 posts with a thousand users in 0.08 seconds on my local machine from 2018, I was incredibly happy.

Programming isn‚Äôt just writing code on things you are familiar with, programming is solving new problems, exploring the unknown and better solutions.

I wish you all the best and thanks for reading! See you in the next post!
